chief_complaint.definition: A heart checkup done before surgery to make sure your heart is healthy enough to safely undergo anesthesia and the planned procedure.
A doctor's approval confirming that your heart can safely handle the medications used to put you to sleep during surgery.
A minimally invasive surgical procedure where a small camera and instruments are inserted through tiny incisions to repair problems inside the shoulder joint.

history_of_present_illness.definition: A heart attack, which occurs when blood flow to part of the heart muscle is blocked, causing damage. You experienced this in June 2020.
Small mesh tubes placed inside a narrowed or blocked artery to hold it open and restore blood flow. Two were placed in your right coronary artery during your heart attack treatment.
One of the main blood vessels that supplies oxygen-rich blood to the heart muscle, specifically the right and bottom portions of the heart.
A medical evaluation to confirm your heart is safe enough for the upcoming surgery and anesthesia.
A minimally invasive surgery using small incisions and a camera to repair shoulder problems.
A specific arthroscopic method where three small incisions (portals) are made around the shoulder to insert the camera and surgical instruments.
Pain or discomfort in the chest area, which is a common warning sign of heart problems, though in your case you did not experience this typical symptom during your heart attack.
The area between your shoulder blades on your back. This is where you felt pain during your heart attack instead of typical chest pain.
Pain felt between the shoulder blades. In your case, this pain was present before and after your heart attack, and an orthopedic doctor attributed it to muscle problems.
Death of tissue due to lack of blood supply — in your case, referring to the heart muscle damage from your 2020 heart attack.
A type of cholesterol-lowering medication. Statins are important for patients with heart disease to help prevent further artery blockages.
The brand name for atorvastatin, a cholesterol-lowering medication you were prescribed after your heart attack.
A generic cholesterol-lowering statin medication (brand name Lipitor) used to reduce the risk of future heart attacks by controlling cholesterol levels.
Muscle pain or aching. You reported this as the reason you stopped taking your statin medication.
Medication used to lower high blood pressure. You reduced your dose to half after your blood pressure dropped significantly following your heart attack.
A non-surgical procedure where a catheter is threaded through a blood vessel to open a blocked coronary artery, often with stent placement. This was done during your heart attack treatment.
A condition where the arteries supplying blood to your heart become narrowed or blocked by plaque buildup, which led to your heart attack.
A mental health condition involving persistent feelings of sadness or loss of interest. You are currently being treated with antidepressant medication.
Medication prescribed to help manage depression symptoms.
A medical condition involving excess body weight that increases the risk of heart disease, diabetes, and other health problems.

review_of_systems.definition: Relating to the heart and blood vessels. This section reviews symptoms related to your heart health.
Pain or discomfort in the chest, often a sign of heart problems. You denied having this symptom currently.
Chest pain or pressure caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. You are not currently experiencing this.
Pain between the shoulder blades, which in your case was the unusual symptom you experienced during your prior heart attack.
A heart attack — damage to the heart muscle from blocked blood flow. You experienced this in June 2020.
After a myocardial infarction (heart attack). This refers to the period following your 2020 heart attack.
Relating to the muscles and bones. This section reviews your muscle and joint symptoms.
Muscle pain or soreness. You experienced this, which was initially thought to be caused by your statin medication.
A cholesterol-lowering medication. Muscle pain is a known possible side effect of statins.
Medication used to treat depression. You are currently taking this, though specific details were not reported.

physical_exam.definition: An ultrasound test of the heart that uses sound waves to create images showing how your heart chambers and valves are working.
Lying flat on your back. This is one of the positions used during your heart ultrasound.
Lying on your left side. This position helps get better ultrasound images of the heart.
Listening to sounds inside the body (such as heart and lung sounds) using a stethoscope.
Basic measurements of body function including blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, and breathing rate.

assessment.definition: A condition where plaque builds up inside the arteries that supply blood to your heart, narrowing them and reducing blood flow.
A heart attack. Yours occurred in June 2020 and was treated with stent placement.
Small mesh tubes placed inside blocked arteries to keep them open. You have two in your right coronary artery.
One of the main arteries supplying blood to the heart. This is the artery that was blocked during your heart attack.
Chest pain or discomfort caused by reduced blood flow to the heart. Your doctor noted you are not currently experiencing these.
Heart-related reasons that would make a procedure unsafe. None were found for your planned surgery.
Medication that puts you into a deep sleep during surgery so you feel no pain and are completely unconscious.
The inability to take statin medications due to side effects like muscle pain. Your doctor is evaluating whether you truly have this condition.
Muscle pain. You reported this as the reason for stopping your statin, but since the pain only partially improved after stopping, it may not be caused by the medication.
A generic cholesterol-lowering statin medication (brand name Lipitor) that you stopped taking two months ago.
The brand name for atorvastatin, your prescribed cholesterol-lowering medication.
Abnormally high cholesterol levels in the blood. Without your statin medication for two months, your cholesterol is likely uncontrolled, which is a concern.
Fatty deposits that build up inside artery walls, which can narrow arteries and potentially cause heart attacks. Going without statin therapy increases the risk of this.
Another heart attack. Your doctor is concerned about this risk because your cholesterol has been uncontrolled without statin therapy.
A medical condition of significantly excess body weight that raises your risk of heart disease and other health problems.

plan.definition: Official medical approval that your heart is healthy enough to safely undergo surgery and anesthesia.
Heart-related reasons that would make surgery unsafe. None were identified for you.
A minimally invasive procedure using small incisions and a camera to repair your shoulder.
Medication that puts you completely to sleep during surgery. Your heart has been cleared for this.
Relating to the heart and blood vessels.
Treatment with cholesterol-lowering medication to protect your heart and arteries from further plaque buildup.
The brand name for atorvastatin, the cholesterol-lowering medication your doctor instructed you to restart immediately.
A generic statin medication (brand name Lipitor) used to lower cholesterol and reduce heart attack risk.
A waxy substance in the blood. High levels contribute to plaque buildup in arteries. Yours needs to be controlled with medication.
The buildup of fatty deposits inside artery walls that can narrow or block blood flow to the heart.
The blood vessels that supply oxygen-rich blood to your heart muscle. You already have disease in these arteries.
A blood test that measures different types of cholesterol and fats in your blood to assess your heart disease risk.
Your prescribed cholesterol-lowering medication that you are being asked to restart and monitor for muscle pain side effects.
Muscle pain. If your muscle pain does not worsen after restarting the statin, it may suggest the pain is not related to the medication.
The inability to take statin medications due to side effects. If confirmed, your doctor will consider alternative cholesterol-lowering options.
Medications or treatments designed to reduce cholesterol and fat levels in your blood to protect against heart disease.
A brand name for enteric-coated aspirin, a blood-thinning medication that helps prevent blood clots in your coronary stents and arteries.
A medication that thins the blood and helps prevent clot formation, which is important for patients with coronary stents.
A beta-blocker medication that slows the heart rate and lowers blood pressure, commonly prescribed after a heart attack to protect the heart.
Medication used to treat depression, which you are currently taking as part of your regular medications.
